sen.j: 二条天皇（にじょうてんのう、康治2年6月18日（1143年7月31日） - 永万元年7月28日（1165年9月5日））は第78代天皇（在位保元3年8月11日（1158年9月5日） - 永万元年6月25日（1165年8月3日））。
sen.e: Emperor NIJO (July 31st, 1143 - September 5th, 1165) was the 78th Emperor. (his reign was September 5th, 1158 - August 3rd, 1165.)
Emperor Nijo (July 31, 1143 - September 5, 1165) was the seventy-eighth Emperor (his reign was from September 5, 1158 to August 3, 1165).
Emperor Nijo (July 31, 1143 - September 5, 1165) was the seventy-eighth Emperor (his reign was from September 5, 1158 to August 3, 1165).

sen.j: 名を守仁（もりひと）という。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Morihito.
His posthumous name was Morihito.
His posthumous name was Morihito.

sen.j: 後白河天皇の第一皇子。
sen.e: He was the first Prince of Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA.
He was the first prince of Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
He was the first prince of Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 母は源有仁の養女・贈皇太后源懿子（よしこ）。
sen.e: His mother was MINAMOTO no Tamotsu's adopted daughter, the Empress Dowager, posthumously conferred, MINAMOTO no Yoshiko.
His mother was MINAMOTO no Tamotsu's adopted daughter, the Empress Dowager (posthumously conferred), MINAMOTO no Yoshiko.
His mother was MINAMOTO no Arihito's adopted daughter, the Empress Dowager (posthumously conferred), MINAMOTO no Yoshiko.

sen.j: 外祖父は藤原経実。
sen.e: His maternal grandfather was FUJIWARA no Tsunezane.
His maternal grandfather was FUJIWARA no Tsunezane.
His maternal grandfather was FUJIWARA no Tsunezane.

sen.j: 祖父である鳥羽法皇の后・美福門院の養子となる。
sen.e: He was adopted by his grandfather, the retired Emperor TOBA's (in pious life) Empress, Bifuku mon in.
He was adopted by his grandfather, the retired Emperor Toba's (in the pious life) Empress, Bifuku mon in.
He was adopted by his grandfather, the Cloistered Emperor Toba's Empress, Bifuku mon in.
sen.cmt: retired→Cloistered法皇をCloistered Emperorとすると、そのあとに続く(in the pious life)と意味が重なるため、(in the pious life)は削除しました。

tit.cmt: "Biography" -> "Brief Personal History" に変更しました。

sen.j: 生母の懿子（よしこ）が急死したことで祖父・鳥羽法皇に引き取られ、美福門院により養育された（『山槐記』）。
sen.e: After the Emperor 's birth mother, Yoshiko died suddenly, he was taken in by his grandfather, the retired Emperor TOBA in pious life and raised by Bifuku mon in. ("Sankai ki")
After the Emperor 's birth mother Yoshiko died suddenly, he was taken in by his grandfather, the retired Emperor Toba in the pious life and raised by Bifuku mon in ("Sankai ki").
After the Emperor 's birth mother Yoshiko died suddenly, he was taken in by his grandfather, the Cloistered Emperor Toba and raised by Bifuku mon in ("Sankai ki").
sen.cmt: retired→Cloistered法皇をCloistered Emperorとすると、そのあとに続くin the pious lifeと意味が重なるため、in the pious lifeは削除しました。

sen.j: 近衛天皇が即位しており、更に同じく美福門院の養子として先に入っていた重仁親王（崇徳上皇の長男）がいたために皇位継承の望みは薄く、仁平元年（1151年）10月、僧侶となるために伯父である覚性法親王のいる仁和寺に入った（9歳）。
sen.e: While Emperor Konoe succeeded the throne, Bifuku mon in already had another older adopted son, Prince Shigehito (Emperor Sutoku's oldest son), thus there was no possibility for Emperor Nijo to succeed to throne, in October 1151 he left for Ninna-ji Temple to become a priest where his uncle, Kakusho Hosshinno /monk-Prince kakusho was. (Emperor was nine years old)

While Emperor Konoe succeeded the throne, Bifuku mon in already had another older adopted son, Prince Shigehito (Emperor Sutoku's oldest son), thus there was no possibility for Emperor Nijo to succeed to the throne; therefore, in October 1151 he left for Ninna-ji Temple to become a priest where his uncle, Kakusho Hosshinno (the monk Prince Kakusho) was (the Emperor was nine years old).

While Emperor Konoe succeeded the throne, Bifuku mon in already had another older adopted son, Prince Shigehito (retired Emperor Sutoku's oldest son), thus there was no possibility for Emperor Nijo to succeed to the throne; therefore, in October 1151 he left for Ninna-ji Temple to become a priest where his uncle, Kakusho Hosshinno (the monk Prince Kakusho) was (the Emperor was nine years old).

sen.j: その後、孫王は仏典をよく読みこなし「ちゑふかくおはしましけり」（『今鏡』）と評判になった。
sen.e: After that 孫王 (grandson of the Emperor) read many Buddhist scriptures, he was well known as "a very smart child'. ("Ima Kagami /The Mirror of the Present")
sen.cmt: 孫王→a grandson of the Emperor? [定訳不明] [ちゑふかくおはしましけり] [定訳不明]
sen.e: Subsequently, 孫王 (grandson of the Emperor) read many Buddhist scriptures, and he was well known as "a very smart child" ("Ima Kagami /The Mirror of the Present").
Subsequently, Sonno (grandson of the Emperor) read many Buddhist scriptures, and he was well known as 'a very smart child' ("Ima Kagami/The Mirror of the Present").
sen.cmt: 孫王→Sonno原文の「」に合わせ"を'に

sen.j: 近衛は病弱で子もいなかったことから、仁平3年（1153年）関白・忠通が鳥羽法皇に孫王への譲位を奏請し、美福門院も崇徳の院政への危惧から孫王の擁立に傾いていった。
sen.e: Since Emperor Konoe was not well and had no children, the chancellor (chief advisor to the emperor), Tadamichi asked an approval to the retired Emperor Toba in pious life, for 孫王 (the grandson of the Emperor) to succeed the throne, Bifuku mon in also supported it as she was concerned about Emperor Sutoku starting his cloister government.

Because Emperor Konoe was not well and had no children, the chancellor (chief advisor to the emperor), Tadamichi, asked the approval of the retired Emperor Toba in the pious life for 孫王 (the grandson of the Emperor) to succeed the throne; Bifuku mon in also supported it, since she was concerned about Emperor Sutoku starting his cloister government.

Because Emperor Konoe was not well and had no children, the chancellor (chief advisor to the emperor), Tadamichi, asked the approval of the Cloistered Emperor Toba for Sonno (the grandson of the Emperor) to succeed the throne in 1153; Bifuku mon in also supported it, since she was concerned about Emperor Sutoku starting his cloister government.
sen.cmt: retired→Cloistered法皇をCloistered Emperorとすると、そのあとに続くin the pious lifeと意味が重なるため、in the pious lifeは削除しました。

sen.j: 久寿2年（1155年）7月に近衛が崩御すると「王者の議定」が行われて、孫王即位までの中継ぎであることを条件に、雅仁親王（後白河天皇）が即位した。
sen.e: After Emperor Konoe died in July 1155, it was decided in 'Imperial agreement' that Prince Masahito (the Emperor Go-Shirakawa) enthroned under the condition of being in the position until 孫王 succeed the throne.

After Emperor Konoe died in July 1155, it was decided in 'Imperial agreement' that Prince Masahito (the Emperor Go-Shirakawa) enthroned under the condition of being in the position until 孫王 succeed the throne.

After Emperor Konoe died in July 1155, it was decided in 'Imperial agreement' that Prince Masahito (the Emperor Goshirakawa) enthroned under the condition of being in the position until Sonno succeed the throne.

sen.j: 8月仁和寺から戻った孫王は、9月親王宣下を蒙り「守仁」と命名され即日立太子、12月に元服、翌年3月には美福門院の皇女・しゅ子内親王を妃に迎えるなど、美福門院の全面的な支援を受けた。
sen.e: In August 孫王came back from Ninna-ji Temple, he was ordered to become Crown Prince and was named 'Morihito' in September, then had a coming-of-age ceremony in December, he married to Princess Shushi who was Bifuku mon in's daughter on the following year of March, thus he had all the support from Bifuku mon in.
sen.cmt: 親王宣下→to title Prince [定訳不明]
sen.e: In August 孫王came back from Ninna-ji Temple, whereupon he was ordered to become the crown prince and was named 'Morihito' in September, then had a coming-of-age ceremony in December; in March of the following year he married Princess Shushi, who was Bifuku mon in's daughter, so he had all the support from Bifuku mon in.

Sonno returned from Ninna-ji Temple in August, whereupon he was ordered to become the crown prince and adopt the name 'Morihito' in September; he then had a coming-of-age ceremony in December and in March of the following year, he married Princess Shushi, as a result of which he had the complete support of Princess Shushi's father, Bifuku mon in.
sen.cmt: 文法。 “so he had all the support from” 日本語で「全面的支援」となっているが、英語では「何に対する支援」と明確にすることが必要。I have edited this to make it read a little more smoothly, but I don't think there is any need to specify what the support was in regard to. For one thing, the Japanese doesn't tell us and for another it seems clear to me that because Sonno had married his daughter, Bifuku mon in would support Sonno whenever necessary.

sen.j: 保元3年（1158年）8月、後白河は守仁に譲位する（二条天皇）。
sen.e: In August 1158, Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA passed the throne to Morihito. (Emperor NIJO)
In August 1158, Emperor Go-Shirakawa passed the throne to Morihito (Emperor Nijo).
In August 1158, Emperor Goshirakawa passed the throne to Morihito (Emperor Nijo).

sen.j: これは「仏と仏との評定」（『兵範記』保元3年8月4日条）によるもので、美福門院が信西に強く要求して実現したものであった。
sen.e: This was done by 'Buddha and Buddha rating' (Hei han ki" August 4th, Hogen 3), Bifuku mon in demanded it to Shinzei strongly and came true.
This was done by 'Buddha and Buddha rating' (Hei han ki," August 4, Hogen 3), since Bifuku mon in demanded it of Shinzei strongly and it came to be.
This was done by 'Buddha and Buddha rating' ("Hei han ki," August 4, 1158), since Bifuku mon in demanded it of Shinzei strongly and it came to be.

sen.j: 二条天皇を支える勢力として、藤原伊通（美福門院の従兄弟）・藤原経宗（二条生母・懿子の弟）・藤原惟方（二条の乳母・俊子の子）らが集結して、二条親政派を形成した。
sen.e: There was a support group of Emperor NIJO's directly ruled government, people in the group were FUJIWARA no Koremichi (Bifuku mon in's cousin), FUJIWARA no Tsunemune (Emperor NIJO's birth mother, Yoshiko's brother) and FUJIWARA no Korekata. (Emperor NIJO's educator, Toshiko's child)

There was a support group of Emperor Nijo's directly ruled government, and the people of the group were FUJIWARA no Koremichi (Bifuku mon in's cousin), FUJIWARA no Tsunemune (Emperor Nijo's birth mother, Yoshiko's brother) and FUJIWARA no Korekata. (Emperor Nijo's educator, Toshiko's child).

There was a support group of Emperor Nijo's directly ruled government, and the people of the group were FUJIWARA no Koremichi (Bifuku mon in's cousin), FUJIWARA no Tsunemune (Emperor Nijo's birth mother, Yoshiko's brother) and FUJIWARA no Korekata (Emperor Nijo's educator, Toshiko's child).

sen.j: ここに、二条親政派と後白河院政派の対立が始まった。
sen.e: This was the beginning of the confrontation between Emperor NIJO's directly ruled government force and Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA force.
This was the beginning of the confrontation between Emperor Nijo's directly ruled government force and the force of Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
This was the beginning of the confrontation between Emperor Nijo's directly ruled government force and the force of Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 二条は美福門院に育てられたこともあり、実父・後白河との関係は冷淡なものであった。
sen.e: Since Emperor NIJO was brought up by Bifuku mon in, he did not have close relationship with his father, Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA.
Because Emperor Nijo was brought up by Bifuku mon in, he did not have a close relationship with his father, Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
Because Emperor Nijo was brought up by Bifuku mon in, he did not have a close relationship with his father, Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 平治元年（1159年）12月平治の乱が起こると、二条は反乱軍に幽閉されるが清盛の六波羅邸へ避難する。
sen.e: In December 1159 there was a Heiji War and Emperor NIJO was confined to the oppositions, but he escaped to Kiyomori's Rokuhara tei.
In December 1159 there was a Heiji War and Emperor Nijo was confined by the oppositions, but he escaped to Kiyomori's Rokuhara tei.

In December 1159 there was a Heiji War and Emperor Nijo was confined by the oppositions, but he escaped to TAIRA no Kiyomori's Rokuhara tei (TAIRA clan's villa located between Gojo and Shichijo, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto city).
sen.cmt: Kiyomori's Rokuhara tei の説明を加えてました。

sen.j: 『平家物語』によると女房車の中を覗いた武士が、二条を女房と見誤ったとする。
sen.e: According to "the Tale of the Heike", it is said one of the Samurai thought Emperor NIJO was a court lady when he had a look inside the court lady's carriage.
According to "the Tale of the Heike,' it is said the one of the samurai thought Emperor Nijo was a court lady when he had a look inside the court lady's carriage.
According to "the Tale of the Heike,' it is said that one of the samurai thought Emperor Nijo was a court lady when he had a look inside the court lady's carriage.

sen.j: 女性のような美貌を持った美男子だったという。
sen.e: It is said that the Emperor was a feminine looking handsome man.
It is said that the Emperor was a handsome but feminine-looking man.
It is said that the Emperor was a handsome but feminine-looking man.

sen.j: 乱が終結した直後の12月29日に美福門院の八条邸に行幸し、翌正月には太皇太后・藤原多子を入内させる（二代の后）。
sen.e: On December 29th just after the War finished, the Emperor went to Hachijo tei where Bifuku mon in was, and on New Year of the following year, the Empress of ex- ex-Emperor, FUJIWARA no Tashi made an entry into the court as his Imperial Consort.
sen.cmt: 太皇太后→the Empress of ex-ex-Emperor [先々代の天皇の皇后、定訳不明]
sen.e: On December 29, just after the war ended, the Emperor went to Hachijo tei where Bifuku mon in was, and on New Year of the following year the Empress of the ex-emperor, FUJIWARA no Tashi, made an entry into the court as his Imperial Consort.

On December 29, just after the war ended, the Emperor went to Hachijo tei (Hachijo villa) where Bifuku mon in was, and on New Year of the following year the Empress of the ex-emperor, FUJIWARA no Tashi, made an entry into the court as his Imperial Consort.
sen.cmt: Hachijo tei の説明を加えてました。

sen.j: 『平家物語』は多子の入内を二条の独断とするが、後見の美福門院や側近の経宗・惟方がこのような重大問題に関与しなかったとは考えにくく、二条の立場を固めるための政略的な婚姻と推測される。
sen.e: It is said in "The Tale of the Heike", Tashi's was allowed to make her bridal entry to the court as Emperor's court lady due to Emperor's own authority, however it is hard to think his guardian, Bifuku mon in and his close aides, Tsunemune and Korekata did not get involved in making decisions on such an important issue, thus it is presumed this was an arranged engagement for the Emperor to be in the better political position.

It is said in "The Tale of the Heike," Tashi was allowed to make her bridal entry to the court as the Emperor's court lady due to the Emperor's own authority; however, it is hard to think his guardian, Bifuku mon in, and his close aides Tsunemune and Korekata did not get involved in making decisions on such an important issue, so it is presumed that this was an arranged engagement for the Emperor to be in a better political position.

It is said in "The Tale of the Heike," Tashi was allowed to make her bridal entry to the court as the Emperor's court lady due to the Emperor's own authority; however, it is hard to think his guardian, Bifuku mon in, and his close aides Tsunemune and Korekata did not get involved in making decisions on such an important issue, so it is presumed that this was an arranged engagement for the Emperor to be in a better political position.

sen.j: しかし、3月に経宗・惟方が後白河の命により配流されて失脚、7月には藤原隆信が院昇殿停止処分を受け、8月には中宮・姝子内親王が病により出家、11月には後見の美福門院が死去するなど二条親政派の要人が次々に消えて、二条の立場は不安定となり後白河院政派が勢力を拡大した。
sen.e: However Tsunemune and Korekata were sentenced to deportation and lost their positions in March, FUJIWARA no Takanobu was suspended to enter into a special temple in the Imperial palace in July, the second consort of the Emperor, Princess Shushi became a nun due to her illness in August, followed by the Emperor's guardian Bifuku mon in's death in November, thus Emperor NIJO's political power wreaked by losing his important people, on the other hand GO-SHIRAKAWA in force took more political power.
sen.cmt: 昇殿 平安時代以降、五位以上の者および六位の蔵人(くろうど)が、家格や功績によって宮中の清涼殿にある殿上(てんじょう)の間(ま)に昇ることを許されたこと。
sen.e: However, Tsunemune and Korekata were sentenced to deportation and lost their positions in March; FUJIWARA no Takanobu was suspended from entering into a special temple in the Imperial Palace in July, the second consort of the Emperor, Princess Shushi became a nun due to her illness in August, followed by the death of the Emperor's guardian Bifuku mon in that November; thus Emperor Nijo's political power was wrecked by losing his important people, while on the other hand Go-Shirakawa, with the support of his force, took more political power.

However, Goshirakawa ordered to sentence Tsunemune and Korekata for deportaion and they lost their positions in March; FUJIWARA no Takanobu was suspended from entering into a special temple in the Imperial Palace in July, the second consort of the Emperor, Princess Shushi became a nun due to her illness in August, followed by the death of the Emperor's guardian Bifuku mon in that November; thus Emperor Nijo's political power was wrecked by losing his important people, while on the other hand Goshirakawa, with the support of his force, took more political power.
sen.cmt: 「後白河の命により」を補いました。。Go-Shirakawa→Goshirakawa

sen.j: 表面的には「院・内申シ合ツツ同ジ御心ニテ」（『愚管抄』）二頭政治が行われたが、両派の対立は深く「上下おそれをののいてやすい心なし、ただ深淵にのぞむで薄氷をふむに同じ」（『平家物語』）という状況であった。
sen.e: On the surface it looked like the government was ruled by two political forces with no confliction, ("Gu kan sho" (A Selection of the Opinions of a fool)), the fighting between both parties were more complicated, the situation was as if 'both scared of each others and were in fear, although their fighting can not be seen on the surface but is was like walking on the thin glass'. ("the Tale of the Heike")

On the surface it appeared that the government was ruled by two political forces with no conflict, but according to "Gu kan sho (A Selection of the Opinions of a Fool)" the fighting between the parties was more complicated; the situation was as if 'both were scared of each other and were in fear, although their fighting could not be seen on the surface but was like walking on the thin glass'. ("the Tale of the Heike").

On the surface it appeared that the government was ruled by two political forces with no conflict, ("Gu kan sho (A Selection of the Opinions of a Fool)"), however the fighting between the parties was more complicated; the situation was as if 'both were scared of each other and were in fear, although their fighting could not be seen on the surface but was like walking on the thin glass.' ("the Tale of the Heike")
sen.cmt: but according to 削除、NCで原文と離れるhowever 補足ピリオドを"内に移動最後のピリオドを削除

sen.j: 二条が頼みとしたのは、藤原伊通と平清盛だった。
sen.e: Emperor gave hope to FUJIWARA no Koremichi and TAIRA no Kiyomori.
Emperor gave hope to FUJIWARA no Koremichi and TAIRA no Kiyomori.
Emperor gave hope to FUJIWARA no Koremichi and TAIRA no Kiyomori.

sen.j: 伊通は太政大臣として二条を補佐し、政道の意見書『大槐秘抄』を著した。
sen.e: Koremichi supported Emperor NIJO as a Grand Minister and he published "Tai kai Sho", political statement.
Koremichi supported Emperor Nijo as a grand minister, and he published "Tai kai Sho," a political statement.
Koremichi supported Emperor Nijo as a grand minister, and he published "Tai kai Hi Sho," a political statement.

sen.j: また乳母・平時子を従三位典侍にするとともに（『山槐記』）、時子の夫・清盛を検非違使別当・中納言にすることで軍事的な後ろ盾とした。
sen.e: The educator, TAIRA no Tokiko was appointed to Ju Sanmi no Nashi no suke, ("Sankai ki") and Tokiko's husband, Kiyomori was appointed to Kebiishi (a police and judical chied) Betto (an equerry), Chu nagon to support military background.

The educator TAIRA no Tokiko was appointed to Ju Sanmi no Nashi no suke, ("Sankai ki") and Tokiko's husband Kiyomori was appointed to Kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) Betto (an equerry), Chu nagon to support the military background.

The educator TAIRA no Tokiko was appointed to Ju Sanmi no Naishi no suke, (Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) vice Minister of Naishinosuke) ("Sankai ki") and Tokiko's husband Kiyomori was appointed to Kebiishi (a police and judicial chief) Betto (an equerry), Chu nagon (equivalent rank to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in the legal codes of the Nara and Heian eras)to support the military.
sen.cmt: “to support the military background.”「後ろ盾」の翻訳が不適切。→“to support the military.” (equivalent rank to Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) in the legal codes of the Nara and Heian eras) 括弧の中の括弧に注意。

sen.j: 応保元年（1161年）9月、後白河と平滋子の間に生まれた皇子憲仁（後の高倉天皇）を皇太子にしようとする陰謀が発覚すると、二条は後白河近臣の平時忠・平教盛・藤原成親・藤原信隆を解官して、後白河の政治介入を停止した。
sen.e: In September 1161, after the conspiracy to let Prince Norihito (later called Emperor TAKAKURA) succeed the Imperial Throne was found out, who was the son of Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA and TAIRA no Shigeko, the Emperor removed Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA's close ades, TAIRA no Tokitada, TAIRA no Norimori, FUJIWARA no Narichika and FUJIWARA no Nobutaka from their position to stop GO-SHIRAKAWA's political involvement.

In September 1161, following the discovery of the conspiracy to let Prince Norihito (later called Emperor Takakura) succeed the Imperial Throne, he being the son of Emperor Go-Shirakawa and TAIRA no Shigeko, the Emperor removed Emperor Go-Shirakawa's close aides, TAIRA no Tokitada, TAIRA no Norimori, FUJIWARA no Narichika and FUJIWARA no Nobutaka, from their positions in order to stop Go-Shirakawa's political involvement.

In September 1161, following the discovery of the conspiracy to let Prince Norihito (later called Emperor Takakura) succeed the Imperial Throne, he being the son of Emperor Goshirakawa and TAIRA no Shigeko, the Emperor removed Emperor Goshirakawa's close aides, TAIRA no Tokitada, TAIRA no Norimori, FUJIWARA no Narichika and FUJIWARA no Nobutaka, from their positions in order to stop Goshirakawa's political involvement.

sen.j: 「主上二条院、世ノ事ヲバ一向ニ行ハセマイラセテ」（『愚管抄』）実権を掌握した二条は、親政の拠点を押小路東洞院の内裏に据えて清盛に警護させた。
sen.e: Ex-emperor NIJOIN focused on two things entirely' ("Gukan sho"), Emperor NIJO took whole control of the politics and established the based of his directly ruled government in the Imperial Palace of Ohi koji higashi no to in, and Kiyomori was in worked as a guard of this place.

Ex-emperor Nijoin focused on two things entirely' ("Gukan sho"), Emperor Nijo took full control of the politics and established power based of his directly ruled government in the Imperial Palace of Ohi koji higashi no to in, and Kiyomori worked as a guard at this place.

Ex-emperor Nijoin focused on two things entirely' ("Gukan sho"), Emperor Nijo took full control of the politics and established power based of his directly ruled government in the Imperial Palace located at Higashi no to in, Oshi koji, and Kiyomori worked as a guard at this place.
sen.cmt: Ohi→Oshi「主上二条院」以下は、後白河の介入を止めさせて親政を確立させるという二つのことに（二行）焦点を当てるという意味にとりましたが、定訳が見つかりませんでした。また、具体的な「二行」の意味については（原文に説明がないため）敢えて訳出しませんでした。「一向」はentirelyの意味にとりました。押小路東洞院の定訳不明ですが、’内裏’のある場所として訳出しました。

sen.j: 12月には美福門院の皇女・あき子内親王に八条院の院号を与えて准母となし、出家していた姝子内親王にも高松院の院号を与えた。
sen.e: In December Prince Akiko, Bifuku mon in's Princess became Junbo and was given the name of Hachijo in, also Princess Shushi, who became a nun, was given the name of Takamatsu in.
sen.cmt: 准母→[定訳不明、(天皇の母に准ずるの意)多く内親王に皇后または院号を賜る時の称]
sen.e: In December Prince Akiko, Bifuku mon in's princess, became a junbo (women who were given equivalent rank of Emperor's birth mother) and was given the name of Hachijo in; moreover, Princess Shushi, who became a nun, was given the name of Takamatsu in.

In December Prince Akiko, Bifuku mon in's princess, became a junbo (women who were given equivalent rank of Emperor's birth mother) and was given the name of Hachijo in; moreover, Princess Shushi, who became a nun, was given the name of Takamatsu in.
sen.cmt: junbo の説明を加えてました。

sen.j: さらに、忠通の養女・藤原育子（むねこ、実父は徳大寺実能）を中宮として、関白・基実とも連携して摂関家も自らの下に取り込むことに成功した。
sen.e: Also Tadamichi's adopted daughter, FUJIWARA no Muneko (Muneko, her father was Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI) became the second consort of the Emperor, so the Emperor was supported by the chancellor (chief advisor to the emperor), Motozane and he succeeded to take control of other clan [family] eligible for regents.
sen.cmt: 摂関家→the clan [family] eligible for regents
sen.e: Also, Tadamichi's adopted daughter, FUJIWARA no Muneko (Muneko, the daughter of Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI) became the second consort of the Emperor, so the Emperor was supported by the chancellor (chief advisor to the Emperor) Motozane and he succeeded in taking control of other clans [families] eligible for positions as regents.

Also, Tadamichi's adopted daughter, FUJIWARA no Muneko (the daughter of Saneyoshi TOKUDAIJI) became the second consort of the Emperor, so the Emperor was supported by the chancellor (chief advisor to the Emperor) Motozane and he succeeded in taking control of other clans [families] eligible for positions as regents.
sen.cmt: Muneko, 繰り返しになるので削除

sen.j: 応保2年（1162年）には叔父の経宗を召還する一方、自らを呪詛した時忠・源資賢を配流するなど着々と政治基盤を固めていった。
sen.e: In 1162, the Emperor recalled his uncle, Tsunemune, on the other hand, Tokitada and MINAMOTO no Sukekata who made a curse towards the Emperor were sentenced to deportation to gradually establish the base of his own government.

In 1162 the Emperor recalled his uncle, Tsunemune, while on the other hand Tokitada and MINAMOTO no Sukekata who had made a curse toward the Emperor, were sentenced to deportation in order to gradually establish the basis of his government.

In 1162 the Emperor recalled his uncle, Tsunemune, while on the other hand Tokitada and MINAMOTO no Sukekata who had made a curse toward the Emperor, were sentenced to deportation in order to gradually establish the basis of his government.

sen.j: 二条は悪僧・神人の統制令や荘園整理など、信西の政策を踏襲して積極的な政務を展開する。
sen.e: The Emperor issued a regulation to control Akuso and Jinin or the manorial control system, he established positive polical ruling by following Shinzei's policy.
The Emperor issued a regulation to control Akuso and Jinin or the manorial control system, and established positive political ruling by following Shinzei's policy.

The Emperor issued a regulation to control Akuso (monk who does not follow the regulation in priesthood) and Jinin (a maiden in the service of a shrine) or the manorial control system, and established positive political ruling by following Shinzei's policy.
sen.cmt: Akuso and Jinin説明を補いました。

sen.j: 政治から排除された後白河は信仰の世界にのめりこみ、蓮華王院を造営して供養の日に二条の行幸と寺司への功労の賞を熱望するが、二条が拒んだことから後白河は恨みを抱いたという（『愚管抄』）。
sen.e: Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA was removed from the politics and he became deeply involved the religion, it is said he built Rengeo in and wished to visit Emperor NIJO on the special memorial day, also wished to have a reward for hard work of his religious activity, however Emperor refused to do so and Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA felt bitter about Emperor NIJO. ("Gukan sho")

Emperor Go-Shirakawa was removed from politics and became deeply involved in religion; it is said that he built Rengeo in and wished to visit Emperor Nijo on the special memorial day, and that he also wished to have a reward for hard work of his religious activity; however, Emperor refused to do so and Emperor Go Shirakawa felt bitter about Emperor Nijo. ("Gukan sho").

Emperor Goshirakawa was removed from politics and became deeply involved in religion; it is said that he built Renge o in and wished Emperor Nijo to come and see him to Renge o in on the special memorial day, and that he also wished to have a reward for hard work of his religious activity; however, Emperor refused to do so and Emperor Goshirakawa felt bitter about Emperor Nijo. ("Gukan sho")
sen.cmt: Rengeo→Renge oGo-Shirakawa→Goshirakawa最後のピリオドを削除「供養の日に二条の行幸と」ですが、行幸とは天皇が外出することを意味するので、この場合「供養の日に二条天皇に蓮華王院まで来てほしい」という意味で訳を修正しました。

sen.j: 蓮華王院には荘園・所領が寄進され、二条は後白河の院政復活の動きに警戒心を抱くことになる。
sen.e: The manor and private land were given to Renge o in, Emperor NIJO started to have suspicions towards Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA to start ruling cloister government.
The manor and private land were given to Renge o in, Emperor Nijo started to have suspicions toward Emperor Go-Shirakawa in starting to rule the cloister government.
The manor and private land were given to Renge o in, Emperor Nijo started to have suspicions that Emperor Goshirakawa in was starting to rule a cloister government.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “toward Emperor Goshirakawa in starting to rule the cloister government.” => “that Emperor Goshirakawa in was starting to rule a cloister government.”

sen.j: 長寛2年（1165年）2月、太政大臣の伊通が亡くなり、自らも病に倒れた。
sen.e: In February 1165, Grand Minister, Koremichi died, and the Emperor himself became ill.
In February 1165, Grand Minister Koremichi died and the Emperor became ill.
In February 1165, Grand Minister Koremichi died and the Emperor became ill.

sen.j: 6月には前年に生まれた実子の順仁親王（六条天皇、中宮・育子の養子）に譲位し、7月に押小路東洞院で崩御した。
sen.e: In June he abdicated and passed the throne to his son born the previous year, Prince Nobuhito (Emperor ROKUJO), the second consort of an emperor, Muneko's adopted son), he died in July at Oshikoji Higashi no toin.

In June he abdicated and passed the throne to his son, who'd been born the previous year, Prince Nobuhito (Emperor Rokujo), the second consort of an Emperor, Muneko's adopted son); he died in July at Oshikoji Higashi no toin.

In June he abdicated and passed the throne to his son, who'd been born the previous year, Prince Nobuhito (Emperor Rokujo, the second consort of an Emperor, Muneko's adopted son); he died in July at Oshikoji Higashi no toin.

sen.j: 二条は優れた人物で「末の世の賢王におはします」（『今鏡』）と賞賛され、愚昧とされた父・後白河とは対照的だった。
sen.e: Emperor NIJO was a fine person, he was praised as 'good Emperor in degenerate age' ("Imakabami"), opposite to his ignorant father, Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA.
Emperor Nijo was a fine person, praised as 'a good Emperor in a degenerate age' ("Imakabami"), opposite to his ignorant father, Emperor Go-Shirakawa.
Emperor Nijo was a fine person, praised as 'a good Emperor in a degenerate age' ("Imakagami"), opposite to his ignorant father, Emperor Goshirakawa.

sen.j: 一方で、後白河との対立は生涯に渡って解消されることはなく、「孝道には大に背けり」（『源平盛衰記』）という世評もあった。
sen.e: On the other hand, the Emperor opposed to Emperor GO-SHIRAKAWA all his life, some people said 'Emperor NIJO did not respect his father' ("Genpei Jusui Ki").
On the other hand, the Emperor had opposed Emperor Go-Shirakawa all his life, and some people said 'Emperor Nijo did not respect his father' ("Genpei Jusui Ki").
On the other hand, the Emperor had opposed Emperor Goshirakawa all his life, and some people said 'Emperor Nijo did not respect his father' ("Genpei Josui Ki").
Hogen (April 27th, 1156) - April 20th, 1159
Hogen (April 27, 1156) - April 20, 1159
Hogen (April 27, 1156) - April 20, 1159
Heiji April 20th 1159 - January 10th, 1160
Heiji April 20, 1159 - January 10, 1160
Heiji April 20, 1159 - January 10, 1160
Eiryaku January 10th, 1160 - September 4th, 1161
Eiryaku January 10, 1160 - September 4, 1161
Eiryaku January 10, 1160 - September 4, 1161
Ouho September 4th, 1161 - March 29th, 1163
Ouho September 4, 1161 - March 29, 1163
Oho September 4, 1161 - March 29, 1163
Chokan March 29th, 1163 - June 5th, 1165
Chokan March 29, 1163 - June 5, 1165
Chokan March 29, 1163 - June 5, 1165
Eiman June 5th, 1165 - (August 27th, 1166)
Eiman June 5, 1165 - (August 27, 1166)
Eiman June 5, 1165 - (August 27, 1166)

sen.j: 京都市北区 (京都市)平野八丁柳町の香隆寺陵（こうりゅうじのみささぎ）に葬られたとされる｡
sen.e: It is said that the Emperor was entombed in Koryuji no misasagi, Haccho Yanagi-cho Town, Hirano, Kita Ward, Kyoto City
It is said that the Emperor was entombed in Koryuji no misasagi, Haccho Yanagi-cho Town, Hirano, Kita Ward, Kyoto City
It is said that the Emperor was entombed in Koryuji no misasagi, Haccho Yanagi-cho Town, Hirano, Kita Ward, Kyoto City
